description.narrative: this project is established to support both global policy dialogue/debate on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation as well as the strengthening of institutional frameworks, systems and accountability mechanisms at the country level.

participating-org.narrative: Department of Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development
Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Republic of korea
SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Mechanism in place to ensure global dialogue informed by on-the-ground evidence on effective development cooperation. Number of countries have a national monitoring framework that measure the quality of partnerships. Number of countries that have institutional frameworks and/or strategies that manage development cooperation and finance in a coherent way. Visibility, as measured by website presence, online community activity, and high-level events of the GPEDC globally.

comment.narrative: No strong systematic mechanisms that links country, reigonal and global dialogue that is evidence-based from country efforts for making development cooperation effective. 47 countries participated in the first GPEDC monitoring exercise (proxy baseline). 90 programme countries have aid management strategies, but only a few have coherent policy frameworks and strategies that manage development cooperation and finance. Approximately average 5,000 access to the GPEDC website ; 489 members registered in the GPEDC online community space;3 High-Profile side events in 2014

At least 80 countries undertaking the Global Partnership monitoring framework. The global progress report based on the Global Partnership monitoring is published prior to the Senior Level Meeting. The increased number of countries have strengthened policy framework and/or institutional mechanisms to support more effective management of diverse development resources including development cooperation. The Knowledge Sharing Platform launched. The successful deliberation of the Senior Level Meeting, which positions the Global Partnership in the context of the 2030 Agenda.

86 programme countries have undertaken the Global Partnership monitoring framework. The OECD-UNDP Joint publication: Global Progress Report was published, with all 86 country monitoring profiles available at the GPEDCs website. The compendium of country level effective development cooperation published. The Knowledge Sharing Platform launched with at least 100 knowledge products available. The Senior Level Meeting successfully brought together over 500 participants, with the Co-Chairs Statement agreed and published.

The new Global Partnership monitoring framework and process developed for endorsement by the Steering Committee. At least 10 countries undertake the Action Dialogues for Effective Development Cooperation. The Co-Chairs and Steering Committee strategically leads the review of the Global Partnership, which aims to strengthen the function and impact of the Global Partnership. The vision of the next High-Level Meeting endorsed, which will set a clear roadmap for the HLM 3 in 2022. At least 2 substantive Steering Committee held to continue providing strategic direction despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

Key areas of indicator revision and development for the new Global Partnership monitoring framework was endorsed, together with a new approach to monitoring. T 6 countries have completed the Action Dialogues for Effective Development Cooperation. The independent review of the Global Partnership completed, with a set of recommendations for the future direction of the Global Partnership. The Global Partnership Knowledge Sharing Platform saw an increase in traffic with 540 new practitioners and policymakers joined, 325 new resources shared and 50 events added to the Platform’s portal. The GPEDC website generated 454,614 unique page views (vs. 322,122 in 2020), with 291,971 users (vs. 221,683 in 2020) out which 288,763 were new users (vs. 220,402 in 2020). The roadmap to the High-Level Meeting endorsed, through 2 substantive virtual Steering Committee undertaken .

The new Global Partnership biennale Work Programme launched. The vision and direction of the new Global Partnership monitoring framework endorsed by the Steering Committee. New areas of the Global Partnership endorsed with much wider partners leading the effort for more effective development cooperation. At least 2 substantive Steering Committee meeting held to provide the strategic direction of the Partnership. The functionality and usability of the Global Partnership website and the Knowledge Sharing Platform improved.

The Global Partnership 2020-2022 Work Programme endorsed and launched in 2022 May. The Work Programme benefited greatly from active engagement of Steering Committee and programme countries on priority areas of the Global Partnership. The need for the Global Partnership monitoring reform endorsed. The Steering Committee endorsed a comprehensive reform of the Global Partnership monitoring, to strengthen the relevance and usability for programme countries while simplifying the monitoring. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the Steering Committee met twice virtually to endorse the work programme and provided strategic direction for the implementation of the programme. The new Global Partnership website launched in mid-2020 with much user friendly features (easier navigation between the website and the Knowledge Sharing Platform). The Partnership KSP has 1400 users and 600+ resources.

A guide(s) on the new Global Partnership monitoring produced, with a dozen of countries committed to undertake a new Global Partnership monitoring in 2023. Additional 6-10 countries undertake the Action Dialogues for Effective Development Cooperation. The OECD/UNDP joint publication on making development cooperation more effective produced and published before the High-Level Meeting. The traffic to the KSP and the website increased with new users; and robust and targeted communication campaign undertaken to increase stakeholder engagement and promote political attention toward the High-Level Meeting in Dec 2022, through a partnership with the UN SDG Action Campaign. A hybrid High-Level Meeting organised under the leadership of the HLM3 host and the co-chairs, with 300-500 in-person attendance and 500+ virtual participants. The refined functions of the Global Partnership, governance and working arrangement including the function of the OECD/UNDP Joint Support Team endorsed at the HLM3. At least 2 substantive and decisive Steering Committee held to lead political and high-level stakeholder engagement toward a successful and impactful HLM3.
